snippet.textDisplay: It doesn't mean she is inaccurate. Just because there are limited psychiatrists, does not mean that therefore it is OK for GPs to prescribe. To your point however, if you are trained and experienced in this area (so few GPs are though), then perhaps, yes.  Unfortunately, the number of GPs who actually make things worse by prescribing SSRIs and Benzodiazepines at unnecessarily high doses, who do not titrate patients, and who do not follow-up and monitor the patient, outweighs those who do it well. She is not wrong - it is safer to go to a psychiatrist. In places where people do not have access to a psychiatrist, then there is a case to be made for that - but again, a GP can actually do harm to the patient.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've only ever been prescribed anti-depressants from my GP, they also refer me to additional specialists when needed, that's what they're trained to do.
Also, interesting factoid, my partner got referred straight onto a psychiatrist who prescribed meds on the first session. He didn't consult with anyone or do any checking of history to see what else my partner was taking. He actually prescribed something that conflicted with another med and was only picked up by the pharmacist when my partner went to collect it. Oops

snippet.textDisplay: I personally believe anti depressants just dope you up and make you foggy. I have mental illness that i've been struggling for 16 years (im 28). I went to see a Councillor in the beginning and it just made me feel judged. My mental illness stems from isolation and exclusion. I know the cure to my depression is simply the lack of a girlfriend and the inability to express love and receive love. The world beat the kindness out of me and mistook it for weakness. I got walked all over on . Coming from a broken family with no idea how to raise me and expected the school system to take care of me and set me up for life when in fact thats not what they do. I was a latch key kid and I kept all my thoughts to myself. My parents only got mad at my grades not realizing the reason for my less than stellar performance was because I was not receiving the adequate attention and affection I needed to excel. We live in this superficial world and fear of rejection is the primary battle I deal with. My potential was squandered and I am set back by a decade. I also got to experience a really dark decade and period in my life. Yippee. But this darkness has led me to become a stronger person with discipline and has opened up new knowledge, opportunities and appreciation for things that I would never have understood had I not gone through this catastrophic failure in my life. Unless you were given a good parent I do believe scarcity and hardship is the only way to understand the discipline necessary to understand business and money management. Necessity of money is needed to pursue wealth. I was given everything I wanted but not what I needed. ie. I was spoiled and my parents are rich. I hated waking up early for work. I hated work but now I know that this is life and everybody has to work. I could not develop the drive to take action and take the steps to unfuck my life until it was absolutely necessary. Ie. I was complacent and like to smoke weed all day and play games. It was only until I was cut off that I had to learn the fundamentals of creating wealth like developing cash flow and budgeting and actually having the discipline to work everyday towards your goals. Perhaps this is fate and it's woven into my soul that this is the way things must have gone in order for me to develop the character needed to be a leader and to change the world as was my original intention.

I see a prescriber because I can't get into see the Physiologist. She specializes in the meds I take. I had my primary put on medication and I am so glad I see the prescriber. My primary takes care of my thyroid, but most recommend go to a endocrinologist.
I don't think she meant that you shouldn't take medication from your primary, but the better option is a going to be someone who specialize, if you can. More people should have that option and they don't. It might be because of insurance or whatever. Or people don't want others to find out. Their to ASHAMED, to go to the Psychologist, who would want them to do other therapy. Most just want to put the bandage on and not think about the blood gushing out. This is all about the STIGMA OF MENTAL HEALTH.

snippet.textDisplay: I was misdiagnosed by my family care doctor, and GYN, both whom gave me benzos and antidepressants. I went into a psychotic mania from the benzos both times, and was not referred to a psychiatrist. Luckily my husband did research and got me OFF the antidepressants. I finally saw a psychiatrist that a therapist recommended and was given proper diagnosis (I'd been having bipolar symptoms for years) and proper medication. Years later, a family practice doctor that KNEW of my bipolar disorder prescribed an antidepressant for my teenage son, and what happened? He went manic and OD'd on MY benzos. Luckily we got him to an ER quickly and he was fine. I understand that family care doctors are the first in line for mental health, but their lack of knowledge nearly killed me and my son.

snippet.textDisplay: Wow...I generally don't leave comments after videos, but thank you for addressing this. I have fibromyalgia, which includes chronic pain, as well as an ADHD diagnosis I recieved in my late 20s. I'm grateful I didn't hear her opinion before I received my much needed, affordable healthcare from my PCP. Each appointment my health concerns are addressed as well as personal guided questions about my mental health and it's honestly impacted my life in a way I never thought it would. My P.A. team knows me well and I'm open and honest about my mental health. I would never change anything about the care I receive for any amount of money. If anything I'd pay out of pocket if I had to. Thank you for addressing this, I really greatly appreciate it!

snippet.textDisplay: In the UK, our primary care dr's are called GP's (general practitioners). if you go to your GP with a mental health problem, anything from depression to the extreme in mental health, they can prescribe the more common antidepressants but they will refer you to CBT or trauma services (this includes psychiatrists, who will diagnose). So your GP can prescribe lower doses etc but a psychiatrist will prescribe more relevant meds. Our GP's will also discuss if you want to try meds or not or just want therapy or both. GP's are the first step, we can't simply go from A to C without B.

So your GP can prescribe lower doses etc but a psychiatrist will prescribe more relevant meds. Our GP's will also discuss if you want to try meds or not or just want therapy or both. snippet.textDisplay: This fucks me off for several reasons. Gaga addressed that access to care was the issue. Antidepressants and anti psychotics are NOT a fully understood science yet and GPs can often do significantly more harm in prescribing them than if a licensed psychiatrist was. I have been under the mental healthcare system for 6 years, and tried 12 different medicines for my complex, chronic conditions. Several of these, prescribed willy nilly by unqualified nurses and doctors without proper consultation put me at severe risk and aggravated psychotic symptoms within me. Setting my recovery back by years because of unspecialised doctors attempting to fix complex mental health problems is unacceptable, and exactly what gaga was advocating against; we need more study, and more psychiatrists to balance out thw overstretched systems, not to simply mistreat people and risk their health and lives by dishing out antidépressants etc without full understanding. She's right. The system is fucked and people aren't getting the help they need.

snippet.textDisplay: There are about 28,000 psychiatrists in the U.S., but there are also an estimated 106,500 psychologists in the United States. Psychology should almost always be the first step in mental health, not psychiatry...the key difference is drugs and drugs are not needed for many health problems or at the very least should generally not be considered a long term solution, which getting antidepressants from a MD could cause depending on the MD.

snippet.textDisplay:
Not all doctors are as compassionate and kind as you Dr. Mike. Doctors are human too and aren't perfect.

I had depression and on my first appointment, I was given anti depressant. This medicine made me feel numb and it made me feel worse. I thought, "Am I supposed to feel like a robot for the rest of my life?" I stopped going after 2 more appointments.

Honestly, what I needed was some actual advice and a better plan on how to overcome my mental illness. I believe that would be a better long term solution. Medicine is just a bandaid over my problem.

I'm yet to find a good psychiatrist/therapist. Wish there was a faster way to find good doctors.

snippet.textDisplay: You are wrong Dr. Mike. What you are describing is called professional encroachment. Please stop prescribing mental health medicine when you have no idea if that person has depression or is bipolar, is suffering from Parkinson's or PSP, or is even having something real. All of that is only known by tests and a clinical interview and depending of the issue, the person should be attended by a psychologist and maybe referred to a psychiatrist, or by a neurologist and then referred to a neuropsychologist.

snippet.textDisplay:
I really see both sides of the argument here. Firstly, to those that think celebs should stay out of this, I have to disagree. No they are not professionals in this field, but they do have a platform to speak out and help erase the stigmas around mental health and medication. Imagine being 16 and depressed, feeling you're messed up, broken, and alone. You feel judged by the world. And then an idol you really look up to talks about the subject and shares your struggles. It completely alters your perspective and that is so important. We need to see more and more of this to normalize the issues.

I definitely understand why it is important for family medicine doctors to be able to prescribe medications and be the first responders, but it isn't always that easy. I started having mental health issues at a young age and have been on various prescription for ten years. I've moved all over for college and grad school, etc. And every primary Dr I've come in contact with feels very uncomfortable prescribing my medications. Some are willing to at least give me a small amount until I get a referral, but some won't do it at all. In a perfect world it would be much easier. Because it can take an incredibly long time to get in with a specialist. ESPECIALLY if you are under 18, because even fewer psychiatrist sub-specialize in pediatrics. Not everyone is Dr. Mike and is willing and competent in the field.

Lastly, I think Lady Gaga could have made a slight adjustment in her wording that would make both of you correct. As Dr. Mike said, lots of people suffer from anxiety and depression and don't necessarily need a specialist. But for those that have more complicated or multiple issues, a specialist is a MUST. I don't think she was trying to insult primary drs, but rather she was making the point that the health care and insurance industries need to make that manageable. Because not everyone can afford the help they need and if a PM puts them on the wrongs meds it can be really damaging.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don’t think primary care doctors are incapable of dealing with mental health, but it’s an unfortunate reality that not all primaries are good or do what you’re suggesting.

I had a primary that I really liked and trusted, and one day I came in and described having my first panic attack and before I was even done my story he was writing me a prescription for Xanax. I said I didn’t want to take medication, what other options did I have? And he said I should consider an anti depressant too, which felt extreme when all I had was a few panic attacks due to a work situation. It made everything feel much more intense than what I had thought before my visit. I asked about CBT since I had read that it’s proven to be just as effective as medication and he told me to call the mental health hotline on the back of my insurance card. That was it. I couldn’t believe I got so little help from him, when in every other aspect over the years, I always felt he was a great listener and doctor. It genuinely made my anxiety worse to have a doctor react to my recent issues that way and it’s made me wary of looking to primary care physicians for mental health help since. So I hope with more trusting patients, there can also be more primaries that don’t just look to writing someone a script right away if that’s not an option they’re asking about.

snippet.textDisplay:
TIP: GET DIAGNOSED!
I was diagnosed with F40.1 (Social Anxiety Disorder) and along that I knew that I was depressed aswell. So I went about the years from therapy to therapy and was treated for both. Even though I was only diagnosed with F40.1 not depression because they all thought I already was and just treated it.
Fast forward to 2019: I wanted to go to a special clinic because it got really bad and they declined it because I never had an offical diagnosis for depression. I got it a few months later but you can only go into such a special clinic if you have had a diagnosis for a long period of time. So yeah, not getting a diagnosis actually harms me now because I have to wait at least a year before I am able to apply again.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm fine with primary care doctors prescribing mental health medication, but I think they should also refer to a therapist, as a rule. (I'm not a big fan of psychiatrists to be honest.) In my experience antidepressant and anti-anxiety medications only address one part of the problem and a psychologist or other therapist is key to addressing another part of the problem. A lot of primary care doctors I've been to seem to view mental health disorders like depression primarily as chemical imbalances that can be treated with medication alone and do not consider the underlying psychology much.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm fine with primary care doctors prescribing mental health medication, but I think they should also refer to a _therapist,_ as a rule. (I'm not a big fan of psychiatrists to be honest.) In my experience antidepressant and anti-anxiety medications only address one part of the problem and a psychologist or other therapist is key to addressing another part of the problem. A lot of primary care doctors I've been to seem to view mental health disorders like depression primarily as chemical imbalances that can be treated with medication alone and do not consider the underlying psychology much.

Dr. mike
ALL the general care doctors I have met trough my entire life have one thing in common: NONE of them was comfortable treating my mental health issue. They always stated that they didnt feel comfortable giving me a diagnostic and they didnt feel comfortable giving me a treatment.
I had an ER doctor having a follow up with me in a public clinic(I dont have a family doctor so this is the alternative they put in place in my city) He was honest and self-aware enough to tell me that medical school dont trained them to treat mentally ill patient. its like when you have a pneumonia(or wtv that should be hospital matter and is not a cold) and your parent still think your faking to be sick


Doctor are basically being the ignorant parent that think you arent as sick as you are because they cant pinpoint the symptoms.

snippet.textDisplay:
The relationship you feel you have with your patients is not the relationship most patients feel they have with their doctors. Therefore, the disconnect with your view and Lady Gaga. Most of us spend most of our time during our doctor visits with nurses and only see the doctor for 10 minutes. We are herded through the office so quickly I don't think our primary doctors take the time to understand our mental health. I've seen doctors even ignore the mention of depression after they asked the patient if he was depressed.

The issue is that are the primary doctors just throwing more pills at us or are they actually helping to treat mental health? There are people taking antidepressants for years, but they are still in the same condition. Patients can spend years having dosages changed without any real resolution or improvement. One primary doctor prescribed Xanax for 5 years and never told the patient "You're not getting better. You need psychological help."

I've sat around dinner tables hearing about how many of these people are taking pills, but none have been to a counselor. That's crazy.

Pills don't fix everything. And without psychological counseling, the right medication may never be prescribed.

Aren't antidepressant medications prescribed just like opioids? Every doctor is prescribing them, but are they really needed and have they actually been effective? If people were dying from antidepressants, we would reconsider the prevalent use and prescriptions.

For many patients, a primary care doctor visit costs the same or more than seeing a counselor. Also, most people get some free psychological counselor visits, so you actually save money.

So, I understand Gaga's point and your point. I feel she was taking about her primary doctor not having the skills to address her specific mental health issues and that she wasted a lot of time in pain by not seeing a psychologist earlier. There are medical specialties for a reason.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm torn about this. I think both the statement Gaga made, and the statements made in this video are correct. Nothing is quite so black and white as you both made it out to be.

I would reject anything my pcp wanted to put me on as far as psychiatric meds go, not because I don't trust her, but rather because I see my hematologist and other specialists far more often than I do my pcp. I have more trust in someone who will see me 4-8x a year than someone who sees me once.

Additionally, I'd much rather be evaluated by a specialist than my pcp. A longterm mapped out treatment plan that I can discuss in depth and fully understand is better than a 3 question test to determine if I've become depressed/more depressed and just prescribing whatever med based on my bodyweight and age. Because that's what's done. Or sometimes a referral is given to go see a psychiatrist, but not as often.

Not to mention the tons of cases where a psychiatrist has to ween the patient off of the wrong meds to put them on the right meds. Meds given by a pcp. And I think that that's the crux of the point being made. If pcps mainly keep a once or twice a year tally, hand out referrals or are meant to discuss further options with you which in a lot of cases involve a specialist, then why are they giving you a prescription for something that's going to thoroughly alter the chemical balance of your body? I wouldn't go to a pcp for heart surgery, but I would ask her for a recommendation or referral to a cardiologist.

The mental health sector is strained because there's not enough general funding, not because of the amount of ppl going to see psychiatrists or psychologists. For that reason a pcp definitely should be a first step for those with access to more, and should be trained to handle basic cases properly if access isn't available for a patient.

snippet.textDisplay: I completely agree that celebrities should avoid giving medical advice without strong medical backup. The most egregious example in my mind was Tom Cruise’s rants about psychiatric medications. I’m a clinical psychologist with 27 years of private practice experience. My concern with PCP’s prescribing psychiatric medications is they need to thoroughly assess issues such as the past presence of symptoms of mania. I’ve had several patients with histories of manic episodes who presented to their PCP with depression.  They were prescribed SSRI’s which pushed them into full blown mania. If you don’t ask patients about previous episodes with manic symptoms they don’t tell you about them. I’ve never had patients with bipolar disorder seek medication when they’re manic - they generally like the energy and goal directedness they experience in that mood state. They seek help when they’re in depressive phases.
snippet.textOriginal: I completely agree that celebrities should avoid giving medical advice without strong medical backup. snippet.textDisplay: I have had myself, my brother and my mum go through depression and mental health issues and I think in a lot of cases people think it’s easier to throw pills at an issue before anything else. I feel that counselling can do sooooo much for tackling the issues at the source and I didn’t need anti depressants for mine. However the are a lot of cases where antidepressants are needed to take the edge off while counselling is going on. And the anti depressants for both mum and brother were prescribed by our local GP who has treated us for as long as I can remember. Of course this is all anecdotal and personal experience but I don’t think she really knows what she’s talking about
snippet.textOriginal: I have had myself, my brother and my mum go through depression and mental health issues and I think in a lot of cases people think it’s easier to throw pills at an issue before anything else. I feel that counselling can do sooooo much for tackling the issues at the source and I didn’t need anti depressants for mine. However the are a lot of cases where antidepressants are needed to take the edge off while counselling is going on. And the anti depressants for both mum and brother were prescribed by our local GP who has treated us for as long as I can remember. Of course this is all anecdotal and personal experience but I don’t think she really knows what she’s talking about

snippet.textDisplay:
In the UK, I went to my GP (general practitioner) with extreme prolonged anxiety (couldn't think straight and was desperate for a solution.) I booked the appointment hoping to get a referral to therapy because it was a specific event that caused the anxiety. I like being able to have a conversation about my symptoms with my doctor, and there were other things I wanted to discuss with a therapist that had been bothering me since before the anxiety got worse.

After I explained that I was there because I was experiencing intense anxiety and wanted to be referred to talk therapy or something along those lines, my doctor (called Dr. Dry) asked me "do you have anxiety" - I'd never been diagnosed, so I started to explain that, and how it had come about. (My history.) She interrupted me and said "just say yes or no." I hesitated but said yes. (Oops! I believe that's called self diagnosis.) She asked the same question about depression. I started to explain again (I suspect PDD - persistent depressive disorder - or something relating to childhood trauma, or possibly undiagnosed and therefore untreated ADHD) but again I was interrupted. I said yes. She wrote me a prescription for a high dose of citalopram and told me to book a follow up appointment for 2 weeks later. That was the extent of our interactions during my appointment. No guidance on what to expect by way of side effects, nor what the purpose of the medication was, or the relative strength of dosage I was given. No explanation at all. No care taken to ensure there wasn't an underlying cause for my anxiety. Nothing.

I had a very unpleasant experience after the first dose and visited a pharmacy to get advice about going off course after the first dose, which they didn't recommend. I did it anyway because I hadn't received any guidance and couldn't be sure things would get any better over the two weeks before the follow up. I went to the follow up with an almost full pack of citalopram, and the GP seemed personally offended. I have no regrets, and felt better off overall for taking control of my experience. Unrelated, but the GP retired shortly after. I no longer fully trust doctors because of that experience.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've only watched the first one and a half minutes, but I just wanted to come in and say how fantastic your advice is.
My depression started when I was just 10 years old. There were many points in the following years to come when I really couldn't function due to my depression. But it wasn't until I was 23 that one of my friends finally convinced me to see a doctor. I started medication and seeing a counsellor but it was too late and a month or two later I was admitted to hospital.
Back as a teenager I'd self diagnosed myself with depression and thought I could do it on my own. Now 27, I know just how wrong I was. I'm so grateful to the friend who convinced me to get help, who took me to counselling and who brought me to hospital, to my current therapist, who has taught me how to reshape my thoughts and to the health care system in my country of residence. I wonder how differently my life may have unfolded if I'd gotten help sooner.

snippet.textDisplay: My nurse indirectly prescribed me antianxiety meds and so saved my life. She knew my family medical history, in that she treated literally every member of my immediate family, and knew that "stuff" was going on. She worked with a doctor, who was technically my primary care provider, but that i saw twice in my whole life. I "broke", mentally, because of Reasons, and could not leave my house. I could get dressed, stand in the doorway holding my car keys, and could NOT bring myself to leave the house. I had gone to work the day before, and been ok. When I realized that there was a problem (immediately) I called my nurse (theoretically my doctor) and she, with my doctor's backing, phoned in my prescription. With her faith and support, I got through it all ok, and was able to, with therapy, work my way to a better state, and no longer take the medications. she is kind of my hero.

Hi Dr. Mike! First I would just like to say I love your videos and the knowledge you spread. Thank you so much for using this as a platform. I am in the medical field as well (med/surg nurse). I found this video very interesting and you expressed an opinion opposite of what I would think and was wondering if I could email you? It's in regards to using a FP to prescribe antidepressants as a first line vs going to see a specialist. I always thought it would be better to see a specialist for therapy sessions vs starting medicine right away. I believe professionals in healthcare could learn a great deal from each other and would love to hear an FPs reasoning and point of view as well as ask some follow up questions. It would also help to educate me as family and friends often come to me for advice and I would hate to lead someone astray from such an important topic. I will also read the articles you posted. Thank you!
denny3027@gmail.com

snippet.textDisplay: a few years ago, I was having a very difficult time finding a psychiatrist to take my insurance. during that time, my GP was able to prescribe me the medication I was on at the time, and offered to work with me if I needed a dose change or another medication added. I do need to see a psychiatrist because I have severe mental illnesses, but I’m thankful my GP was there as my ally during a difficult time. family medicine is hugely underrated, yet so important to public health and well-being.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think it's particularly harmful when you see a specialist before other things have been properly ruled out. My husband and I were pretty thankful for our family care doctor, because she decided to evaluate the potential physical factors that may cause depression-like symptoms before giving him anything for depression...and it turned out to be a vitamin D deficiency that was causing his symptoms. (we live in an area that gets a lot of snow...so winter means we don't get a whole lot of sun on our skin...>.<) After he started taking a multi-vitamin and vitamin D supplements, his symptoms started to decrease.
Thank goodness for good doctors! Though, I've also had some bad doctors who were too quick to refer as well. x.x

snippet.textDisplay: I work in Canada so maybe it’s different here, but I have to disagree with Dr Mike and not because Lady Gaga said so. But because there are many scary side effects of these drugs that require medical watch. I find that drs are too quick to prescribe a depression med because they don’t have the specialty to know the right questions to ask. I have had too many suicides that could have been prevented and so many people struggling because their depression is actually anxiety and the med they were prescribed is wrong. But they stay on it because they don’t believe that feeling good can be accomplished. Dr Mike is supporting a broken system in his statements and that is why I struggle.
